protocol_name: Cat Bite on Human - General Protocol

infection_risk.why_dangerous: Cat teeth are needle-like and create deep puncture wounds that seal quickly on the surface, trapping bacteria deep in tissue where it proliferates rapidly

immediate_actions.action: Stop any bleeding by applying gentle pressure with clean cloth
Wash wound immediately with soap and water
immediate_actions.warning: DO NOT scrub vigorously - this can damage tissue and push bacteria deeper

immediate_actions.action: Apply povidone-iodine, betadine, or hydrogen peroxide antiseptic
Cover with sterile bandage or gauze
immediate_actions.note: Do not seal wound tightly - allow drainage

mandatory_if: Any cat bite that breaks skin
Bite on hand, wrist, foot, or near joint
Bite on face or near eyes
reasons: 50-80% infection risk (highest of all animal bites)
Hand/wrist bites can cause tendon/joint infections rapidly

antibiotics.note: Prophylactic antibiotics recommended for ALL cat bites due to high infection risk

tetanus.required_if: Last shot >5 years ago OR unknown vaccination history

questions_to_answer: Is cat's rabies vaccination status known and current?
Is cat behaving abnormally (aggression, lethargy, disorientation)?
Can cat be observed for 10 days?
Has cat had contact with wild animals?
pep_required_if: Cat cannot be observed for 10 days
Cat dies or becomes sick during observation

pep_protocol.day_0: HRIG (immune globulin around wound) + Vaccine dose 1

monitoring.check_frequency: Daily for first 5 days, then every 2-3 days
warning_signs_infection: Swollen lymph nodes (especially near bite site)
emergency_signs: Loss of function in bitten area
Joint swelling or inability to move nearby joint
monitoring.action_if_signs: Seek immediate medical attention - may need IV antibiotics or surgical drainage

hand_bites.reason: Thin tissue, many tendons and joints, rapid spread of infection
hand_bites.protocol: ALWAYS seek medical attention within 4-8 hours
hand_bites.complication_risk: Permanent damage to tendons, joints if untreated

immunocompromised_patients.protocol: Immediate medical attention, likely hospital admission
immunocompromised_patients.mortality_risk: Up to 30% if infection becomes systemic

children.note: Children more likely to need hospitalization
children.reason: Smaller body mass, bites often on face/neck

what_not_to_do: DO NOT use super glue or tape to close wound
DO NOT apply ice directly to wound
DO NOT delay medical attention (infection can start within 12 hours)
DO NOT assume small bites are safe (puncture depth matters more than size)
prevention_tips: Watch for warning signs: flattened ears, dilated pupils, tail lashing
full_protocol_text: Cat bites carry an exceptionally high infection risk of 50-80%, the highest of all animal bites. This is due to Pasteurella multocida bacteria present in 70-90% of cat mouths, combined with the deep puncture wounds created by their needle-like teeth. These puncture wounds seal quickly on the surface but trap bacteria deep in tissue where infection develops rapidly, often within 12-24 hours. Immediate action is critical: Stop bleeding with gentle pressure for 5 minutes. Immediately wash the wound with soap and water for 5-10 minutes, but do not scrub vigorously as this can damage tissue. Rinse thoroughly under running water for 2-3 minutes. Apply antiseptic such as povidone-iodine or betadine. Cover with sterile gauze. Seek medical attention within 8 hours - prophylactic antibiotics (typically Amoxicillin-clavulanate) are almost always prescribed for cat bites due to the extremely high infection risk. Hand bites are especially dangerous due to tendons and joints. Assess rabies risk based on cat's vaccination status and behavior. Monitor wound for 14 days for signs of infection including redness, swelling, pus, fever, or red streaks. Any worsening symptoms require immediate medical attention.
